bugs.title: CVE-2024-41014 kernel: xfs: add bounds checking to xlog_recover_process_data [fedora-all]

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2024-41014 kernel: xfs: add bounds checking to xlog_recover_process_data [fedora-all]

blocked.short_desc: CVE-2024-41014 kernel: xfs: add bounds checking to xlog_recover_process_data

long_desc.thetext:
In the Linux kernel, the following vulnerability has been resolved:

xfs: add bounds checking to xlog_recover_process_data

There is a lack of verification of the space occupied by fixed members
of xlog_op_header in the xlog_recover_process_data.

We can create a crafted image to trigger an out of bounds read by
following these steps:
    1) Mount an image of xfs, and do some file operations to leave records
    2) Before umounting, copy the image for subsequent steps to simulate
       abnormal exit. Because umount will ensure that tail_blk and
       head_blk are the same, which will result in the inability to enter
       xlog_recover_process_data
    3) Write a tool to parse and modify the copied image in step 2
    4) Make the end of the xlog_op_header entries only 1 byte away from
       xlog_rec_header->h_size
    5) xlog_rec_header->h_num_logops++
    6) Modify xlog_rec_header->h_crc

Fix:
Add a check to make sure there is sufficient space to access fixed members
of xlog_op_header.

Created kernel tracking bugs for this issue:

Affects: fedora-all [bug 2300530]

This issue has been addressed in the following products:

  Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8.6 Advanced Mission Critical Update Support
  Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8.6 Update Services for SAP Solutions
  Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8.6 Telecommunications Update Service

Via RHSA-2024:6297 https://access.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2024:6297

This issue has been addressed in the following products:

  Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8

Via RHSA-2024:7001 https://access.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2024:7001

This issue has been addressed in the following products:

  Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8

Via RHSA-2024:7000 https://access.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2024:7000

More information about this security flaw is available in the following bug:

http://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=2300297

Disclaimer: Community trackers are created by Red Hat Product Security team on a best effort basis. Package maintainers are required to ascertain if the flaw indeed affects their package, before starting the update process.

Reproducers, if any, will remain confidential and never be made public, unless done so by the security team.

Use the following template to for the 'fedpkg update' request to submit an
update for this issue as it contains the top-level parent bug(s) as well as
this tracking bug.  This will ensure that all associated bugs get updated
when new packages are pushed to stable.

=====

# bugfix, security, enhancement, newpackage (required)
type=security

# low, medium, high, urgent (required)
severity=medium

# testing, stable
request=testing

# Bug numbers: 1234,9876
bugs=2300297,2300530

# Description of your update
notes=Security fix for [PUT CVEs HERE]

# Enable request automation based on the stable/unstable karma thresholds
autokarma=True
stable_karma=3
unstable_karma=-3

# Automatically close bugs when this marked as stable
close_bugs=True

# Suggest that users restart after update
suggest_reboot=False

======

Additionally, you may opt to use the bodhi web interface to submit updates:

https://bodhi.fedoraproject.org/updates/new

bugs.title: CVE-2024-41013 kernel: xfs: don't walk off the end of a directory data block [fedora-all]

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2024-41013 kernel: xfs: don't walk off the end of a directory data block [fedora-all]

blocked.short_desc: CVE-2024-41013 kernel: xfs: don't walk off the end of a directory data block

long_desc.thetext:
In the Linux kernel, the following vulnerability has been resolved:

xfs: don't walk off the end of a directory data block

This adds sanity checks for xfs_dir2_data_unused and xfs_dir2_data_entry
to make sure don't stray beyond valid memory region. Before patching, the
loop simply checks that the start offset of the dup and dep is within the
range. So in a crafted image, if last entry is xfs_dir2_data_unused, we
can change dup->length to dup->length-1 and leave 1 byte of space. In the
next traversal, this space will be considered as dup or dep. We may
encounter an out of bound read when accessing the fixed members.

In the patch, we make sure that the remaining bytes large enough to hold
an unused entry before accessing xfs_dir2_data_unused and
xfs_dir2_data_unused is XFS_DIR2_DATA_ALIGN byte aligned. We also make
sure that the remaining bytes large enough to hold a dirent with a
single-byte name before accessing xfs_dir2_data_entry.


long_desc.thetext:
1. Please describe the problem:
zram has a feature where it can writeback to a backing device, this is useful for people who want to use zram but still have the advantage of writeback capability of zswap. My Arch setup for example, uses a swapfile attached as a loop device (because zram backing dev only support devices rn not files), and a systemd timer unit that triggers writeback activity.

2. What is the Version-Release number of the kernel:
6.10.3-200.fc40.x86_64

3. Did it work previously in Fedora? If so, what kernel version did the issue
   *first* appear?  Old kernels are available for download at
   https://koji.fedoraproject.org/koji/packageinfo?packageID=8 :
No

4. Can you reproduce this issue? If so, please provide the steps to reproduce
   the issue below:
  - create a zram device
  - check if /sys/block/zramX/{backing_dev,writeback} exist
  - it does not = CONFIG_ZRAM_WRITEBACK is not applied

5. Does this problem occur with the latest Rawhide kernel? To install the
   Rawhide kernel, run ``sudo dnf install fedora-repos-rawhide`` followed by
   ``sudo dnf update --enablerepo=rawhide kernel``:
No

6. Are you running any modules that not shipped with directly Fedora's kernel?:
No

7. Please attach the kernel logs. You can get the complete kernel log
   for a boot with ``journalctl --no-hostname -k > dmesg.txt``. If the
   issue occurred on a previous boot, use the journalctl ``-b`` flag.
not really needed, so here's proof the kernel isn't built with the support instead
```
cat /usr/lib/modules/6.11.0-0.rc3.20240814git6b0f8db921ab.32.fc42.x86_64/config | grep CONFIG_ZRAM_WRITEBACK
# CONFIG_ZRAM_WRITEBACK is not set
```

Reproducible: Always

I think it would be highly beneficial to enable this feature, as it has already been present in the kernel since 2013. Its use is still optional, so everyone can decide for themselves whether and how to use it or not. The question of data security simply has to be answered by each user. Writing kernel pages to a block device can certainly expose sensitive data.

Thank you for taking this into consideration and for your efforts in relation to this feature.

bugs.title: AMD SFH Driver Causes Memory Errors/ Page Faults

bugzilla.short_desc: AMD SFH Driver Causes Memory Errors/ Page Faults

long_desc.thetext:
Fedora 41 Final blocker tracker bug: https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/BugZappers/HouseKeeping/Trackers

To propose a bug as blocking the Fedora 41 Final release, mark it as blocking this bug, or use the webapp: https://qa.fedoraproject.org/blockerbugs/propose_bug . It will be reviewed according to https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/QA:SOP_blocker_bug_process . If you can, please specify the release criterion that the bug violates. See https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Fedora_Release_Criteria for details on the release criteria.

If the bug is not serious enough to block release but you believe it merits being fixed during a milestone freeze (see https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Milestone_freezes ), you can propose it as a 'freeze exception' instead. To do this, mark it as blocking the bug F41FinalFreezeException . See https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/QA:SOP_freeze_exception_bug_process for the freeze exception process.

I don't understand why bug 2258100 was added as a blocker bug (see discussion
on that bug).  How can I find the justification for it?  (It seems it was
added by some automated process.)

It's not an automated process, it's a person making a proposal through an app. As https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=2258100#c12 says, the person is siosm (Timothee Ravier) and the justification is "Virtualization agent failure in default installation in a QEMU virtual machine".
Thanks Adam.  The issue will be fixed shortly.  See https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=2258100#c14 and following comments.

1. Please describe the problem:

Recently I upgraded my laptop (Ryzen 5 4500U) to F40 via `dnf system-upgrade`. Shortly after logging in the system started to freeze up. It took a bit of troubleshooting to determine this was because the filesystem was going read only.

I thought maybe it was a quirk and installed F40 from scratch which worked fine... At first. After a `dnf update` the problem happened again. I couple of times I was lucky and the problem was caught before writing the corruption to disk. 

I reinstalled F40 and stuck with 6.8.5 for some time (many reboots) without issue. Now that 6.11 has released for F41 I installed it to see if I could reproduce the issue.  It happened on the 2nd boot.


2. What is the Version-Release number of the kernel:

All kernels after 6.8.5

3. Did it work previously in Fedora? If so, what kernel version did the issue
   *first* appear?  Old kernels are available for download at
   https://koji.fedoraproject.org/koji/packageinfo?packageID=8 :

Only the stock F40 kernel (6.8.5) has not reproduced the problem.


4. Can you reproduce this issue? If so, please provide the steps to reproduce
   the issue below:

Usually happens within 50 second to 2 minutes after booting. May be a race condition if it gets farther than that the problem doesn't seem to happen for that whole "boot".


5. Does this problem occur with the latest Rawhide kernel? To install the
   Rawhide kernel, run ``sudo dnf install fedora-repos-rawhide`` followed by
   ``sudo dnf update --enablerepo=rawhide kernel``:

Didn't try, but did try 6.11 from F41 which still had the problem.


6. Are you running any modules that not shipped with directly Fedora's kernel?:

No moduels


7. Please attach the kernel logs. You can get the complete kernel log
   for a boot with ``journalctl --no-hostname -k > dmesg.txt``. If the
   issue occurred on a previous boot, use the journalctl ``-b`` flag.

https://hobbes1069.fedorapeople.org/lspci.log
https://hobbes1069.fedorapeople.org/dmesg-6.10.6.log
https://hobbes1069.fedorapeople.org/journal-6.10.6.log

Interestingly on the last corruption with the 6.11 kernel, `btrfs check` did not find any errors but `btrfs scrub` and `btrfs check --mode=lowmem` did.

The pictures are in the Ask Fedora link in the URL field.
https://lore.kernel.org/linux-btrfs/1079dd1b-b43b-434d-86a6-f65b20b4cb01@app.fastmail.com/T/#u

The dmesg shows a pretty obvious corruption in the node:

[   56.387821] 	key 119 (18446744073709551606 128 2763644928) block 556269568 gen 5817
[   56.387822] 	key 120 (18446744073709551606 128 2773835776) block 1011646464 gen 5752
[   56.387823] 	key 121 (14136236289662124022 254 199011574867967) block 556335104 gen 5817
[   56.387824] 	key 122 (18446744073709551606 128 2796371968) block 554729472 gen 5817

Note that key 121 is completely out of order.
Furthermore the tree node belongs to csum tree, so the objectid should always be (-10ULL), and key type should always be 128,
the key offset should be aligned to 4096.

So the key 121 is definitely corrupted, and since it's a write time corruption and later btrfs check reports no metadata error, but tons of data error,
I guess it's something totally wrong.

Furthermore since the user has ran memtests many times, I do not think it's simple bitflip, so far the corruption is not simple bitflip either.


Do you hit any other problems on another system? Or any luck with LTS kernel?
Fedora doesn't build LTS kernels. And also the problem seems to appear in 6.8 series. Kernel bisect would take a long time, the problem has no known trigger to reproduce.

Created attachment 2048394
Full journal from the 6.11.0 boot

Attached boot journal from 6.11.0.

>Attached boot journal from 6.11.0.

It must be a different boot, there's no errors in this one.

Created attachment 2048395
6.8.5 log showing btrfs curruption

Now I'm really confused. I remember booting 6.11.0 once without issue and then I just rebooted. 6.8.5 is not set as default.

(In reply to Richard Shaw from comment #8)
> Created attachment 2048395 [details]
> 6.8.5 log showing btrfs curruption


>[   80.477826] kernel: BTRFS error (device nvme0n1p6): unable to fixup (regular) error at logical 12381716480 on dev /dev/nvme0n1p6 physical 14302707712
>[   80.477844] kernel: BTRFS error (device nvme0n1p6): unable to fixup (regular) error at logical 12384600064 on dev /dev/nvme0n1p6 physical 14305591296
>[   80.477881] kernel: BTRFS warning (device nvme0n1p6): checksum error at logical 12384600064 on dev /dev/nvme0n1p6, physical 14305591296, root 257, inode 398174, offset 1038708736, length 4096, links 1 (path: usr/local/bin/ollama)
>[   80.477881] kernel: BTRFS warning (device nvme0n1p6): checksum error at logical 12381716480 on dev /dev/nvme0n1p6, physical 14302707712, root 257, inode 398174, offset 1035825152, length 4096, links 1 (path: usr/local/bin/ollama)

This shows a different problem (repeated 5 times, same error though), which is data corruption in two 4KiB blocks in a single file. Since there's only one copy of data blocks, it can't be fixed. But you can replace it by reinstalling the source RPM. The root number is the same for all five, so no snapshots? If there are snapshots I'd expect an error for each snapshot the damaged file is in, but different root values.

If this file system still exists it might be worth doing an offline scrub and file system check: btrfs check --check-data-csum

Is the file system state in comment 9 the same as this comment:https://discussion.fedoraproject.org/t/fedora-40-btrfs-filesystem-corruption-on-6-9-6-10-kernals/129937/38

Strange there's different results between online and offline scrub. I don't have an explanation for that.

Created attachment 2048478
offline btrfs check with lowmem mode from F40 Live USB

Created attachment 2048571
Journal from 6.10.10-debug, locked up on shutdown

Created attachment 2048572
Journal from 6.10.10-debug, locked up on startup.

System locked up in the middle of gnome-session(?) before login name was displayed.

In comment 12:

>[   93.266726] kernel: workqueue: gc_worker [nf_conntrack] hogged CPU for >10000us 19 times, consider switching to WQ_UNBOUND
>[   98.866249] kernel: BUG: Bad page map in process pool-gnome-soft  pte:00000001 pmd:171a9d067
There's a few of these, maybe they're causing the hangs, but I can't tell if they're relevant or what to do about them.

>[ 1358.660141] kernel: BUG: Bad page map in process ollama  pte:fffebe5200022c0d pmd:174dc4067
What are the chances the debug kernel mentions ollama, and in comment 9 btrfs scrub shows the ollama binary has corrupt blocks? The reporter reinstalled the package for this binary prior to installing the debug kernel.

I don't see anything in the startup journal in comment 13.

Created attachment 2048744
Trouble logging in

I tried booting the 6.10.10 debug kernel again and had trouble. I did attempt to login once in gnome-session but it hung. I almost restarted but just decided to let it sit for a while. A short time later it returned SLUGGISHLY to the login menu.

It took a while but I finally got to a terminal (cntl-alt-F4). Still no BTRFS corruption but I was noticing page faults. I eventually gave up and tried to reboot when it finally hung completely.

Could the page faults the debug kernel is catching is what's causing the btrfs corruption?

Hopefully a kernel developer can answer that question. I'm not sure what I'm looking at, and if these are reportable to the kernel or the implicated program. I suspect the kernel doesn't just magically find problems if we aren't running the workload that triggers the problem we're interested in. It may be the debug kernel is finding problems we're not interested in (though they may be reportable)>

It looks like the memory is already corrupted for the memory management part.

Unfortunately I'm not that familiar with the MM part, but it really doesn't look well at all.
If the MM is not doing correctly, no wonder btrfs will reporting errors (or has corrupted csum), especially considering btrfs has a much higher memory usage for its metadata,
thus much easier to be affected by corrupted MM behavior.

Mind to try v6.11 debug kernels and setup a netconsole (in case when things go terribly wrong), and catch the dying messages?
Just want to see if we can get a better log.

I've also taken a look at this with Qu and I'd just like to quickly summarize the status so that we can try to direct gathering the most useful data we can going forward.

We have ~5 reports with full dmesg dumps and they have very little in common except btrfs detecting corruption in some tree structure (key data, item data, in leaf, in node, in various different trees). That corruption has no particular alignment to btrfs structures. It straddles across structs and seemingly uint64s, but tends to be about 16 bytes in size. I am planning to check if there is evidence of any other alignment in the corruptions, since btrfs tree structs are packed, so they have funny alignment.

Mark observed that (all?) the non-koji-builder user reports were from the same HP laptop model. But as far as we know, that model doesn't have anything in common with the builder hosts? Trying to get this aspect of it straight in my head still.

Running with a debug kernel was too slow and didn't seem to reproduce the btrfs errors, but did produce mm warnings.

As has already been said, I believe that this corruption pattern as well as the mm errors hint at some kind of memory corruption as the root cause.

Two ideas for going forward:
1. Is it possible to run the builders with less total debug, but at least KASAN (or maybe KFENCE?) to try to detect the memory corruption problem as early as possible?
2. Can you describe the sort of workload these builder vms do in some detail and I can try to create a particularly mean and thrashy reproducer in the same vein? So far, I have been trying running fsstress and compiling the linux kernel in a loop in a vm with 4G of RAM, but without any success.

Thanks,
Boris

Hi Boris, (Generic) Fedora kernels have KFENCE enabled. The generic and debug configs are here https://gitlab.com/cki-project/kernel-ark/-/tree/os-build/redhat/configs/fedora?ref_type=heads

The only thing in common between the laptops in this bug and builder hosts in bug 2312886, they run the same (or similar) binaries, including the kernel.

I'll investigate the feasibility of building a kernel in Fedora infra (what version do you want us to use? Stick with 6.10.5? Or move to 6.11?) based on generic configs but with the KASAN stuff from debug configs added. The challenge is getting such a kernel signed for UEFI secure boot. Our scratch builds are not UEFI SB signed, so the user either has to sign them (pretty esoteric process), or disable UEFI SB.

Sorry for crossing streams, I meant to post this on that other BZ, I just got them totally confused. My bad!

The last update from Kevin there says that you hit it every couple days on 140 hosts with no hits on 3 hosts running 6.11 I don't think that really exonerates 6.11 if I'm spitballing the numbers correctly here. And we would need whatever we do to run on a substantial chunk of that 140 to be likely to hit anything. So with that in mind, I don't think I care much between 6.10.5 and 6.11; whatever is easier for you to actually deploy to the boxes.

Let me know if there would still be value in running a 6.11.x-debug kernel, OR maybe more interesting, the stock F40 kernel 6.8.5 but the debug version. Except for the one report I actually captured the journal log, I have not had any issues with 6.8.5. I could try to capture the log with netconsole sometime this weekend.

There will be a 6.11 series kernel with generic configs and KASAN enabled available for testing soon. It'll (hopefully) get the information we need without the performance penalties of the full debug kernel. Stay tuned.
See also bug 2315716

Created attachment 2049688
Boot log from 6.11.0-debug

Boot did not complete and locked up while starting services.

Created attachment 2049689
btrfs check --check-data-csum log

Does not find any errors.

Created attachment 2049690
btrfs-check --check-data-csum --mode lowmem

Shows lots of errors.

Please take the check log with both stderr and stdout, the stdout only check results don't help at all.

For the dmesg 6.11 debug, it really shows something totally wrong, without involving btrfs.
So the initial problem may really be something out of btrfs.

My current guess is, this may be some regression on this particular platform. Maybe ACPI or whatever which doesn't avoid reserved memory,
thus causing unexpected memory being modified.

Thus I do not think it's the same as bug 2315716

Created attachment 2049710
btrfs check --lowmem with stderr redirected

Thanks Qu,
Unrelated to the original bug, I think there's a problem with the combination of "-check-data-csum --mode lowmem" showing so many csum errors that don't show up otherwise, or with an online scrub. I'll try to reproduce and report it separately.

I can verify that I can boot fine on both 6.10.11 and 6.11.0 (F41 Beta live USB) by adding "module_blacklist=amd_sfh" to the kernel arguments. 

I'm now following the upstream kernel bug.

Proposed as a Blocker for 41-final by Fedora user chrismurphy using the blocker tracking app because:

 "All known bugs that can cause corruption of user data must be fixed or documented at Common Issues."
https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Fedora_41_Beta_Release_Criteria#Data_corruption

Reporter has tested the work around with Fedora 41 beta live USB, with 6.11 series kernel. That's good.

The loosey goosey part of proposing it as a blocker is it's based on tests of the F41 6.11 series kernel, but with an F40 user space.

(In reply to Chris Murphy from comment #32)
> Reporter has tested the work around with Fedora 41 beta live USB, with 6.11
> series kernel. That's good.
> 
> The loosey goosey part of proposing it as a blocker is it's based on tests
> of the F41 6.11 series kernel, but with an F40 user space.

But it is also a problem with an F40 kernel in an F40 user space (and should also be with an F39 kernel in an F39 userspace).

Discussed during the 2024-10-07 blocker review meeting: [1]

The decision to classify this bug as a AcceptedBlocker (Final) was made:

"This is accepted as a conditional violation of "All known bugs that can cause corruption of user data must be fixed or documented at Common Issues", for affected AMD laptops."

[1] https://meetbot.fedoraproject.org/blocker-review_matrix_fedoraproject-org/2024-10-07/f41-blocker-review.2024-10-07-16.00.log.html

bugs.title: Wifi stops working after upgrade to Fedora 41 Beta: rtw89_8852be fails to probe with error -110

bugzilla.short_desc: Wifi stops working after upgrade to Fedora 41 Beta: rtw89_8852be fails to probe with error -110

long_desc.thetext:
Fedora 41 Final blocker tracker bug: https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/BugZappers/HouseKeeping/Trackers

To propose a bug as blocking the Fedora 41 Final release, mark it as blocking this bug, or use the webapp: https://qa.fedoraproject.org/blockerbugs/propose_bug . It will be reviewed according to https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/QA:SOP_blocker_bug_process . If you can, please specify the release criterion that the bug violates. See https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Fedora_Release_Criteria for details on the release criteria.

If the bug is not serious enough to block release but you believe it merits being fixed during a milestone freeze (see https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Milestone_freezes ), you can propose it as a 'freeze exception' instead. To do this, mark it as blocking the bug F41FinalFreezeException . See https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/QA:SOP_freeze_exception_bug_process for the freeze exception process.

I don't understand why bug 2258100 was added as a blocker bug (see discussion
on that bug).  How can I find the justification for it?  (It seems it was
added by some automated process.)

It's not an automated process, it's a person making a proposal through an app. As https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=2258100#c12 says, the person is siosm (Timothee Ravier) and the justification is "Virtualization agent failure in default installation in a QEMU virtual machine".
Thanks Adam.  The issue will be fixed shortly.  See https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=2258100#c14 and following comments.

1. Please describe the problem:

My wifi doesn't work after upgrading to Fedora 41 Beta. This seems to be because the driver fails to load:

kernel: rtw89_8852be 0000:08:00.0: failed to setup chip information
kernel: rtw89_8852be 0000:08:00.0: probe with driver rtw89_8852be failed with error -110

complete dmesg is attached.

2. What is the Version-Release number of the kernel:

6.11.0-63.fc41.x86_64

3. Did it work previously in Fedora? If so, what kernel version did the issue
   *first* appear?  Old kernels are available for download at
   https://koji.fedoraproject.org/koji/packageinfo?packageID=8 :

It worked with Fedora 40, kernel 6.10.10-200.fc40.x86_64, and broke when I upgraded to Fedora 41 beta, kernel 6.11.0-63.fc41.x86_64. I can do a bisect by manually installing old kernels if you want me to.

4. Can you reproduce this issue? If so, please provide the steps to reproduce
   the issue below:

Yes, it happens every time on boot.

5. Does this problem occur with the latest Rawhide kernel? To install the
   Rawhide kernel, run ``sudo dnf install fedora-repos-rawhide`` followed by
   ``sudo dnf update --enablerepo=rawhide kernel``:

Yes, tried with 6.12.0-0.rc0.20240920gitbaeb9a7d8b60.7.fc42.x86_64 (mockbuild@d4939907b9744057b8e0f6f37bb04de8)

6. Are you running any modules that not shipped with directly Fedora's kernel?:

No.

7. Please attach the kernel logs. You can get the complete kernel log
   for a boot with ``journalctl --no-hostname -k > dmesg.txt``. If the
   issue occurred on a previous boot, use the journalctl ``-b`` flag.

Reproducible: Always

Created attachment 2048483
6.11.0-63.fc41.x86_64 dmesg

Proposed as a Blocker for 41-final by Fedora user nirbheek using the blocker tracking app because:

 Wifi breaks for users on Realtek 8851BE, 8852AE, 8852BE, 8852CE, and 8922AE, which are fairly common cards. In the hands of the typical user who doesn't know about booting an older kernel with GRUB, this leaves the system in an unrecoverable state.

There is a proposed fix on LKML which should probably be backported: https://lore.kernel.org/linux-wireless/20240924021633.19861-1-pkshih@realtek.com/T/
jforbes says he's aware of this and is waiting for upstream review/merge of the proposed patch.
+7 in https://pagure.io/fedora-qa/blocker-review/issue/1679 , marking accepted.
